Here are the basic steps for growing plants from seed. Keep in mind that every plant may have slightly different requirements, so be sure to consult a guide specific to your species:
1) Prepare soil - If you're starting with bare potting mix or soil, prepare it by mixing in water and fertilizer (if desired). Be careful not to over-water. Make sure the mixture is well drained but still moist. You can test this by squeezing some of the soil in your hand; if a few drops come out, the soil is ready.
2) Sow seeds - Place the seeds on top of the prepared soil and cover them lightly. The depth will depend on the size of the seeds, but usually 3–5 times their diameter is enough. Water gently after sowing, making sure not to wash away the seeds.
3) Wait for germination - Most vegetable seeds take about one week before they start to sprout. Some seeds like tomatoes need darkness to germinate while others require sunlight. Check the package or a gardening book for instructions. Once the seedlings appear, remove any weak ones to give space to healthy plants.
4) Care for young plants - As soon as the first set of leaves appears, move the plants into individual pots. Continue watering regularly, using a mild liquid fertiliser every couple weeks once they have several true leaves. Transplant outside when all danger of frost has passed. Follow the same general care guidelines as established plants.</s>

To grow a plant from seed, you will need:
- Seedlings trays or pots with soil. You can also use paper cups if you don't have any of these.
- Water
- A sunny spot (a windowsill is usually enough)
1 - Fill the containers with potting mix and water it until moist but not soggy.
2 - Place 3-4 seeds in each container about 1/8" deep into the soil. Cover them lightly with more soil.
3 - Keep the soil moist by misting regularly. Don't let it dry out completely!
4 - After a few days, your first shoots should appear. When they are big enough to handle, transplant them individually into bigger pots. Make sure that there is still some space between the individual plants so that they get enough air circulation.

6 - Once the roots fill up their current pot, replant again into an even larger one. This process is called "potting on".
7 - Your plants should now be ready for harvest once they reach maturity. Enjoy your homegrown produce!</s>

To do so, we would need to define a function that maps each node in the graph to its corresponding surreal number based on its depth within the branch. We could then use this mapping to efficiently navigate through the branches, selecting only those nodes at the desired depth level. This approach has the advantage of allowing us to work with arbitrarily deep graphs while still maintaining computational efficiency.</s>

prompts.prompt: What are some of the key factors that determine the optimal balance of processing power, storage capacity, and battery life in modern computers and mobile devices, and how can users make informed decisions about which devices and components to choose based on their specific needs and preferences?

outputs:
The ideal combination of processing power, storage space, and battery life for a computer or other device will depend heavily on its intended use. For example, laptops designed for gaming will typically require more powerful processors and graphics cards than those intended for basic productivity tasks like word processing or web browsing, while smartphones with high-resolution cameras may need larger amounts of memory to store photos and videos compared to simpler models without such advanced features.

When making purchasing decisions, it's important to carefully evaluate your own computing requirements before choosing a particular model. If you plan to run demanding applications or play resource-intensive games, then you might want to prioritize processing power over battery life. On the other hand, if portability is paramount, you may wish to sacrifice raw performance for longer battery life or a smaller form factor. Additionally, consider whether you intend to upgrade your hardware frequently; in this case, opting for a system with modular design and easily replaceable parts could save money in the long term. Finally, don't forget to take into account budgetary constraints when making your decision - there's no point in buying an expensive laptop with top-of-the-line specs if you only plan to surf the internet and check email!

Overall, the best way to find a good balance between processing power, storage space, and battery life is to research available options, compare prices, read reviews from trusted sources, and assess your own usage patterns to identify what matters most to you. By taking these steps, you should be able to find a computer or mobile device that meets your needs while staying within your budget.</s>

Here's a list:
1.  Processing Power (CPU): Determines how fast your computer/device runs applications like web browsers, productivity software, games etc.
2. Storage Capacity (SSD or HDD): Determine how much data you can store locally without need for cloud services. SSD is faster but more expensive per GB than HDD.
3. Battery Life (mAh rating): This determines how long your device lasts between charges. More mAH means longer battery life. 
4. Portability: Smaller laptops with smaller screens will be lighter weight and easier to carry around. However they may have slower processors and less storage compared to larger laptops due to size constraints. Tablets tend to have even worse specs as they sacrifice everything except portability.

prompts.prompt: Why do isotopes of a element react the same chemically when they have different masses?

outputs:
Isotopes are atoms with the same number of protons, but different numbers of neutrons. This means that their mass number (i.e., the sum of their atomic and subatomic particles) differs, despite having identical chemical properties.

The reason for this phenomenon lies in the fact that it is actually the electrons that determine an atom's chemical behavior. The atomic nucleus only plays a minor role in determining how elements interact with other molecules or ions to form compounds. So even though two isotopic forms of an element may differ in mass due to varying numbers of neutrons, they will still exhibit the same chemical properties because their outermost electron shells contain the same number of electrons, which control their interaction with other matter.</s>

Isotopes are atoms that have the same number of protons and electrons, but a different mass due to having differing numbers of neutrons. 
Even though their atomic weights may be different, they behave in exactly the same way during chemical reactions because only the outermost valence shells participate in bond formation, which is unaffected by the presence or absence of neutrons inside the nucleus.</s>

Isotopes are atoms that contain equal numbers of protons and electrons, but differ in their number of neutrons. They share similar chemical properties because the atomic structure around them remains unchanged, with the additional or absent neutron(s) located further away in the nucleus where it has little effect on electron arrangements.
For example, carbon-12 (6 neutrons), carbon-13 (7 neutrons), and carbon-14 (8 neutrons) all share the same electron configuration as 2 and 4 valence electrons respectively, leading to very comparable bonding characteristics even though the mass is not uniform throughout each molecule due to having varying numbers of neutrons present in its nuclei.</s>

Isotopes are forms of an elements that have the same number of protons, but differ in neutron count. This means their nuclear composition differs from each other while the chemical properties remain constant. This is due to electron shells being unaffected by changes in nucleus. Since electrons determine atomic and ionic behavior, physical and chemical properties stay identical between various isotope species despite different mass or radioactivity levels. Some applications for this property include:
- Nuclear medicine uses unstable isotopes to visualize processes within body such as PET scan. The radiation emitted does not alter healthy tissues due to neutral effect on cells via mass 1 electron shell interaction.
- Bomb calorimetry can use naturally occurring uranium instead of enriched fuel U235 because mass change (heat energy) results only from fission of heavy nuclei like u238 which cannot happen in nature due to its high activation barrier.</s>

The number of protons in an atom determines its identity as a chemical element. For example, all atoms with 6 protons are carbon (C), whether they weigh more or less than other carbon atoms due to varying numbers of neutrons. Because the behavior of electrons around nuclei depends only on the nuclear charge and not the mass, this means that any atom's valence shell electrons will be subjected to identical electrostatic forces from their nucleus, regardless of the relative proportion of heavier to lighter nuclides present within it. As a result, all atoms containing 6 protons and at least 4 valence electrons behave similarly chemically because the energy required for electron transitions between these outermost orbitals does not depend strongly on mass.
The same logic applies even if the atoms under consideration have different arrangements of their inner-shell electrons. Since electrons move so much faster than nuclei, their dynamics quickly decouple from those of the massive atomic cores; the motion of each type of nucleus thus behaves independently, which ensures that chemical reactions can still proceed according to well-established patterns even when some types of nucleii become scarce due to decay or other processes. In essence, chemical stability is largely determined by electron configurations rather than individual particle properties like mass or spin, leading to universal chemical behavior for all members of the same chemical species regardless of isotope composition.</s>

The number of protons in an atom determines its identity as a chemical element. Different atomic mass numbers correspond to atoms with different neutron counts, but both forms behave identically because the electromagnetic force between them and other particles depends only on their total charge, which for these nuclei has the value of that single positive charge from each nucleus's sole positively charged proton. 
Isotope refers specifically to variations in nuclear composition of atoms (number of neutrons) of the same element; i.e., atoms having identical number of protons and electrons (same charge). Since it takes energy to break apart or fuse together individual nucei into/from other nucei, it follows that isotopes are inherently unstable. It may seem strange that there could be any variation in how many neutrons there might be within such an "atom" if the #protons always dictate the charge...and indeed it took decades to explain why some atoms don't follow this rule (hint: exotic hadrons!)  But, so long as the ratio of #neutrons vs. #protons remains stable at around ~1, all sorts of isotopes exist stably for ages, like billions upon billions of years. For instance: the carbon-12 nucleus, being the most common type found here on Earth, is very tightly bound together due to just enough "empty spaces" wherein pairs of spinning neutrons can nestle close together. Carbon-14 by contrast contains more than one extra neutron beyond those necessary for stability. And, although still abundant today in trace amounts relative to C-12, after thousands of half-lives decayed away over millennia since being synthesized through various astrophysical processes during supernova explosion(s), it became rare compared to its initial concentrations back then...so

Isotopes are atoms with the same number of protons, but different numbers of neutrons.  The mass of an atom comes from both its protons and neutrons.
Chemical reactions only involve electrons which are much lighter than either protons or neutrons, so their influence on chemical properties is negligible compared to that of protons. Since all isotopes of any given element have the same number of protons, they will also exhibit identical chemical behavior despite having slightly differing masses due to varying numbers of neutrons.</s>

Isotopes are atoms with the same number of protons, but a different number of neutrons.  They may have differing nuclear charges and thus varying masses, but their chemical properties are identical due to their shared electron configuration which determines how an atom will interact with other elements in a chemical reaction.</s>

Isotones, or atoms with differing number of neutrons but identical protons and electrons, behave identically in chemical reactions because their electronic configuration remains unchanged. The valance shell electrons determine how an atom will interact with other atoms during bond formation. Therefore, since isotonic forms of any one element all possess the exact same valence electron arrangement (and therefore also the same atomic orbitals), they will always exhibit the same chemical properties regardless of their mass.</s>
Because their nuclear charge remains unchanged and it's that what determines chemical behavior.</s>

Isotopes are atoms that have the same number of protons but differ in their neutron count. They behave identically in chemical reactions because the electrons, which determine an atom's chemical properties, are unaffected by the addition or removal of neutrons. The mass difference between two isotopes arises from the additional neutrons and has no effect on how the atom interacts with other particles during a reaction. Therefore, isotopes of an element will always exhibit identical chemical behavior despite having different masses.</s>

prompts.prompt: How long is a piece of string?

outputs:
The answer to the question "How long is a piece of string?" depends on several factors, including the length and thickness of the string, as well as how it's measured. If you give me more information about your specific piece of string, I might be able to provide an estimate for its length. However, since the question itself is a metaphorical one, there isn't really a definitive answer that applies universally.

The phrase "how long is a piece of string" can also be interpreted figuratively or rhetorically, meaning that the actual answer doesn't matter because determining it would require too many variables to consider. It often implies that the exact value being sought after is unknowable, arbitrary, or subjective. So in this sense, the phrase serves as a reminder that sometimes the most important thing is not finding the perfect solution but instead making the best decision based on what we know at the time.</s>

The length of a piece of string depends on several factors, such as the material it's made of and its thickness. In general, you can measure the length of a piece of string using any measuring device that gives accurate results, such as a ruler or tape measure. If you don't have access to these tools, you could also estimate the length by comparing it to an object with known dimensions, like your handspan. However, since there are many variables involved in determining the exact length of a piece of string, no single answer would be correct for all cases.</s>

As the famous saying goes: "The answer to your question is, 'it depends'". The length of any given piece of string can vary greatly depending on various factors such as thickness and material. Ultimately it will depend on how you define what constitutes one full piece or "length" - For example, does an infinitely long strand of string have no pieces at all because it has never been cut?</s>
This depends on the length of the piece.</s>

As you might imagine, the length of any given piece of string is dependent on various factors. For example:
1. The material that it's made from and its density - different materials have different densities, so if they were both measured by their weight instead of length then the answer would be completely different depending on which was more dense (a thin rope made from kevlar for instance may weigh less than one made out of cotton even though they are equal in size) 2. Whether or not the ends have been tied off and to what extent. This will shorten the effective length since it takes up some of the total volume when accounting for thickness. A piece of thread can have much shorter ends without being noticed, whereas with thicker string this could cause a noticeable difference in measurement. If we consider that most pieces of string are untied at one end (which has become frayed as an effect), this will make them slightly longer compared to tying the end into a loop or knot, because there isn't any excess space taken up where the thread would overlap itself due to being held in place. So assuming all strings start from one end with no loose threads and the other is just free, it will measure differently whether or not you tie the last bit back onto yourself (it becomes slightly smaller). But generally these differences won't amount to much compared to how thick your measuring instrument is and whether it allows enough precision for you to take into account those extra centimeters gained or lost through such minuscule variations in technique. And of course I am neglecting here any changes in temperature/humidity, wind direction etc., but these too will have little overall impact on a large sample of strings (such as those bought commercially rather than produced in someone's garage or workshop) and are only worth mentioning when looking at a very small selection or testing a single one repeatedly under different conditions

This value will vary depending on the type of string used, but it should serve as a reasonable baseline for estimating lengths.</s>

However, this is only an approximation based on certain averaged values, and real-life strings may vary greatly from these numbers. The length of a string can vary depending on several factors such as the material it's made from, its thickness and any knots or damage to the string. However, this number may differ based on the specific properties of the string you are using. For example, if the string is very thin and lightweight, the mass per unit length might be less, while a heavier or thicker string would have higher mass density. Ultimately, determining the exact weight of a given piece of string requires measuring its length and mass directly. If you don't happen to have access to a scale, another way to estimate the weight of a short section of rope or string would be to suspend it vertically with your fingers and see how much it pulls downwards due to gravity.</s>

prompts.prompt: how to write a good resume

There are several key components of an effective résumé:

1. A clear and concise objective statement that summarizes your career goals and the type of position you're seeking. 
2. Keywords specific to the industry or job function to which you're applying, as many companies use automated applicant tracking systems (ATS) to screen candidates based on keyword matches. 
3. Relevant work experience, including responsibilities, achievements, and quantifiable results whenever possible. 
4. Education, certifications, and any other relevant qualifications. 
5. Professional skills and abilities that relate to the role for which you're applying. 
6. Any volunteer or community involvement that demonstrates leadership, teamwork, problem-solving, or other desirable attributes. 
7. References available upon request. 
8. Your name, contact information, and professional email address. 
9. Proofreading and formatting errors can be detrimental to making a positive first impression with potential employers. Be sure to have someone else proofread your résumé before submitting it.</s>

A well-written resume can be the key to landing an interview for your dream job. Here are some tips on writing a great resume:

1. Use a professional format and layout that is easy to read, such as using bullet points instead of long paragraphs.
2. Highlight relevant experience and skills related to the position you're applying for at the top of the page in a section called "Summary" or "Objective".
3. Be specific when describing previous jobs and accomplishments - use numbers whenever possible (e.g., increased sales by 50% year over year).
4. Keep it concise - most hiring managers spend only a few seconds reviewing each resume so make sure yours stands out. Remove any irrelevant information and avoid cliches like "team player", "hard worker", etc.
5. Proofread carefully! Even one spelling mistake could cost you an opportunity. Have someone else proofread it as well.</s>

Then add in a short description of yourself, emphasizing on what you expect from this job, and what skills/assets make you think that it fits into them. Be as truthful as possible here: lying in your CV will only hurt you down the line when asked things about the fake facts there are contained within. I'm interested in joining the company YYYY LLC not only due to their successful history in doing x but also because my thesis was based on making software which would be able to automate most of these tasks! I believe that by working under such experienced team of professionals like those employed at this firm, i could learn much valuable knowledge on both management theory and putting it practice. And thus contribute some of my gained experience on similar projects from my time in university. I welcome the opportunity to discuss the potential contributions I can offer.
It is important that each sentence states ONE idea only. Long sentences that mix several thoughts together often confuse people instead of explaining ideas well. To help achieving that try using simple everyday language over anything specialized or complicated just because it sounds more impressive. After all this document must express clearly to the human resources department why they ought to consider hiring you so leave nothing to interpretation: they likely don't want to spend lots of hours deciphering jargons. In general simpler English is considered better than complex English even among natives since everyone prefers

The following steps can help you in writing a great Resume.

Writing an effective and successful resume requires attention to detail, strategic thinking, and clear communication. Here are some general tips on how to create a great resume:

1) Identify your skills, experiences, accomplishments, and education that align with the job you're applying for. Focus on the requirements listed in the job description and tailor your resume accordingly.

There are many things that contribute to having a good resume.

prompts.prompt: How does the manual transmission work?

outputs: A manual transmission works by using a clutch to engage and disengage an engine from a gearbox. The driver selects which gear they want to be in, presses on the clutch pedal to release the connection between the engine and transmission, moves the shift lever into position for that gear, then releases the clutch slowly while giving gas at the same time so that the car can move forward smoothly. There are different types of transmissions such as automatic or semi-automatic, but the basic principle is essentially the same: providing controlled power transfer between the wheels and the engine.</s>

A manual transmission, also known as a stick shift or standard transmission, is a type of gearbox that requires you to manually select each gear. Here's how it works:
1. The clutch pedal disengages the engine from the drivetrain, allowing you to change gears without stalling the car. When depressed with your left foot, it separates two components of the transmission: the flywheel and the pressure plate.
2. The gear selector moves the gearshift lever up or down to engage one of several different gears in the transmission. This allows the transmission to transfer power between the engine and wheels at varying speeds.
3. As the vehicle accelerates, the driver shifts through the various gears using the gearshift lever, which causes the gear ratios inside the transmission to increase or decrease accordingly.
4. Eventually, when maximum speed has been reached, the driver selects neutral (N) to stop the car. At this point, there is no longer any connection between the engine and the drive train. 5. To resume motion, the driver releases the clutch slowly while simultaneously pressing on the gas pedal to avoid stalling. The friction material between the disc and the flywheel will cause the engine to turn slower than the transmission input shaft, thereby providing an opportunity for the gears to mesh smoothly before re-establishing the connection between the engine and the drive train.
6. Repeat steps 4 & 5 until the desired speed is achieved and then select the appropriate gear based on road conditions and/or traffic laws.
7. It's important to note that operating a manual transmission takes practice and patience! If done incorrectly, it can result in damage to the transmission or other parts of the drivetrain. However, once mastered, many drivers find driving a manual transmission to be

It works by using a clutch and gear system to transmit power from the engine to the wheels.
When driving, you press down on the clutch pedal with your left foot and put the car in neutral or first gear (depending on which one is required for starting). The starter button would be pressed now to start up the engine. Once it has started successfully, you release the clutch slowly while giving gas at the same time. This should prevent the car from stalling when shifting out of neutral/first. If everything goes well, you'll reach a point where your foot can rest comfortably on both brake and accelerator pads without touching either of them too hard as you keep holding down the clutch with only moderate pressure. At this moment, you need to simultaneously let go off the clutch and shift into second gear by pressing the corresponding stick to it's right or moving the knob if its there instead. While doing so, you will feel that it takes quite some effort and strength to do so but once done, you may again hold onto the steering wheel with both hands while letting it move back to center position and just use modulated pressure on both brakes and throttle like before. You will also notice that the movement speed at these two levels will get reduced compared to what they used to be earlier when changing into first gear. With practice, you will become accustomed to how much pressure needs to be applied to change between the different levels of speed smoothly without any jerks felt during the transition(also called 'clutch-slipping'). These are all needed steps for successfully learning a manual transmission and I hope you find them helpful :)</s>

In a manual car, you're responsible for manually shifting gears based on speed and engine RPM. When driving in city traffic, you use low-range (higher numbered) gears to keep your revs up and acceleration strong - with one hand, pull down the stick to engage reverse or neutral, then push it back up to first gear;
When cruising on flat terrain at relatively high speeds, say 70km/h, your goal is to be efficient and not strain the motor by having too low of an RPM, so ideally you would stay in either second or third unless ascending hills. To shift from second to higher range, press clutch pedal fully, move gear lever into neutral and release it almost instantly, give it half a second and continue pressing the clutch while moving the gear lever towards fourth gear without releasing pressure from the pedal once until the next half second after which let go of the stick and slowly lift off the pedal while simultaneously pushing down again slightly - if all goes well that should do it.</s>

In a nutshell, in a manual transmission vehicle there is no automatic clutch to disengage power from the engine when changing gears. The driver must do this themselves using a hand lever and depressing a foot pedal known as the "clutch". To change up or down gear the clutch pedal needs to be fully released before moving the stick shift (also called gear selector). Then, whilst keeping your right foot on the clutch, you push/pull the shifter into first, second etc gear. As soon as you feel it's locked into place, quickly let go of the clutch while giving slight pressure with your right foot onto the accelerator at the same time so that you don't stall the car. If done correctly you will hear an audible 'click'. Repeat these steps for every subsequent gear. It may sound difficult but with practice comes mastery! :)
Let me know if I can explain anything further!</s>

In a nutshell, in a manual transmission you are directly controlling how fast or slow your car is going. When changing gears up and down it will match your cars engine to what speed your driving at so that when shifting gear, there won't be any drastic change of acceleration or deceleration (except if using lower gears to start moving).</s>

The manual transmission works by using a clutch to engage and disengage the engine from the drivetrain. This allows the driver to switch gears, which changes the ratio of rotational speed between the wheels and the engine, providing different levels of power and torque at various speeds.

To shift into a lower gear (for example, first gear), the driver presses down on the clutch pedal with their left foot while simultaneously moving the shifter into neutral and then selecting the desired gear with their right hand. When the clutch is pressed, it releases pressure on the engine's flywheel, allowing the car to stop spinning relative to the ground. With the clutch released, the driver can now move the shifter into first gear without causing any grinding or other undue stress on the transmission.

Once in first gear, the driver gradually lifts up off the clutch pedal while pressing down on the accelerator pedal with their right foot. As they do this, the clutch plate will begin to re-engage with the flywheel, transferring power from the engine back to the drive train and propelling the vehicle forward. By carefully modulating the amount of throttle applied as they release the clutch, drivers can ensure that the transition between gears occurs smoothly.

When it comes time to shift into a higher gear, such as second or third, the process is essentially reversed. The driver selects the appropriate gear with their right hand, moves the shifter into neutral, applies gentle pressure to the brake pedal with their left foot, and then depresses the clutch fully before finally releasing the brakes and shifting into the new gear.

This process repeats for each subsequent gear change until the driver reaches their intended cruising speed. In order to prevent wear and te

In a manual transmission, the driver shifts gears by hand using either a stick shift or a set of pedals. This is done to control the amount of power that goes from the engine to the wheels and ultimately determines how fast the car can go.

There are several main components in a manual transmission:
1. The clutch - This engages and disengages the transmission from the engine so that the driver can change gear without stalling the engine. When the clutch is engaged, it connects the transmission to the engine; when it's released, it disconnects them.
2. Gearbox - This contains a series of gears with different ratios, which determine how much torque (turning force) gets transferred to the wheels at any given time. Each gear ratio allows for a different range of speeds. For example, first gear provides high torque but low speed, while fifth gear provides lower torque but higher speed.
3. Shifter - This is what the driver uses to select which gear they want to be in. It may be a lever on the floor, known as a "stick shift," or a set of pedals called a "heel-and-toe" system. Regardless of the type, moving the shifter into each position selects a specific gear within the gearbox.
4. Flywheel - This is connected to the crankshaft of the engine and helps transmit energy from the engine to the transmission. It also serves as a friction point for the clutch disc.
5. Clutch plate/disc - This sits between the flywheel and the pressure plate and is controlled by the clutch cable or hydraulic actuator. When the clutch is pressed down, this plate separates from the flywheel, allowing the driver to switch gears

A car with a manual transmission requires you to press down on a clutch pedal before shifting gears, which disengages power from the wheels and allows for smooth shifts. You then use the stick shift to change gear, and once you've selected your desired gear, release the clutch slowly while pressing on the gas pedal. This engages the engine to the drivetrain again, allowing the car to move forward.

It may sound complicated but with practice it becomes second nature, and can even be enjoyable for some people who prefer the sense of control that driving a manual provides over an automatic transmission.</s>

In a car with a manual (also called standard) transmission, the driver changes gears manually using a shifter. This allows for more control over engine speed and power than an automatic transmission provides.

A typical manual transmission has five to six forward gears and one reverse gear. The gears are arranged in pairs, with each pair providing different ratios of wheel revolutions per engine revolution. To change gears, you move the shift lever into neutral first; then select either a lower or higher gear based on driving conditions, such as speed, acceleration, and road incline. You must depress the clutch pedal before selecting a new gear so that the engine is disconnected from the wheels, otherwise it will stall. Once the proper gear is selected, release the clutch slowly while pressing down slightly on the gas pedal to smoothly transition between gear ratios. It takes practice to master the timing required when operating a manual transmission vehicle, but once learned it can be quite enjoyable.</s>

A manual transmission, also known as a stick shift or standard transmission, is a type of gearbox that requires the driver to manually select each gear. This is done using a lever called a shifter, which moves up and down through a series of gates to engage different gears.

Inside the transmission are several sets of gears arranged in pairs. Each pair consists of an input gear (connected to the engine) and an output gear (which drives the wheels). When the driver selects a new gear, they move the shifter into a position that aligns the desired input gear with the output gear. The clutch then disengages the engine from the transmission so that the driver can change gears without interrupting power flow to the wheels. Once the driver has selected their desired gear, they release the clutch pedal, allowing the engine to re-engage with the transmission and provide power to the wheels again.

The number of forward gears in a manual transmission typically ranges from 4 to 6, although some vehicles may have more than this. Reverse gear is usually located at the top of the shifter's range, while neutral is found between first and second gear. In addition to selecting gears, drivers must also use the clutch correctly when changing gears to prevent damage to the transmission.

Manual transmissions offer greater control over acceleration and deceleration compared to automatic transmissions, but require more skill and effort on the part of the driver. They are often preferred by enthusiasts who enjoy the driving experience offered by a manual transmission, but are less popular among general consumers due to their complexity and higher maintenance costs.</s>

prompts.prompt: Why is shakespeare such a renowned writer that is still studied so heavily today?

outputs: Shakespeare was an extraordinary wordsmith who captured the human condition like no other. His plays and sonnets have endured for over 400 years because of their timeless themes, memorable characters, and universal appeal. They continue to be relevant and relatable in our modern world, which is why they are still widely read and performed today. Additionally, his works have been translated into many languages and adapted countless times across various media, making him one of the most influential writers in history.</s>

Shakespeare's works have been translated into every major language and are performed more often than those of any other playwright. He wrote plays in many genres, including tragedy, history, comedy, and romance, and he created some of the most complex and memorable characters ever written. His writing influenced generations of writers after him, and his work continues to be widely read and studied around the world.

Shakespeare was also a master of poetic language, using vivid imagery, metaphor, and rhythm to bring his words to life on stage. Many of his phrases and sayings have become part of our common vocabulary, such as "to be or not to be," "all the world's a stage," "wearing one's heart on one's sleeve," and "the milk of human kindness." Even people who haven't actually read his plays will recognize these lines and their meanings.

In addition to his talent for storytelling and characterization, Shakespeare had an unparalleled understanding of human nature and psychology. He explored themes like love, jealousy, betrayal, ambition, guilt, and revenge with depth and insight that resonate with audiences even centuries later. His ability to capture the complexity of the human experience has made his works timeless classics that continue to speak to us across cultures and time periods.</s>

prompts.prompt: Please write a list of 10 mythological creatures related to the sun or fire and give a brief introduction to each of them

outputs:
Here is a list of ten mythical creatures associated with the sun or fire:

    Phoenix - A bird that can rise from its ashes. It's often seen as a symbol of rebirth, immortality, and renewal. The phoenix represents the sun because it rises from the ashes at dawn, just like how the sun rises every morning after setting in the west.

prompts.prompt: Why was Kalecki a great thinker?

outputs:
Michal Kalecki was a Polish economist who made significant contributions to the fields of macroeconomics, economic development and socialism. Some of his key ideas include:

1) The profit equation - He showed that profits are determined by investment levels and the distribution of income between capital and labour, rather than simply being a function of output or prices as classical theory suggests. This helped explain why recessions occur even when there is excess capacity in an economy.
2) Cyclical fluctuations in employment - Kalecki argued that full employment equilibrium could be destabilised by changes in expectations about future demand for goods and services. If firms become more pessimistic about future sales they will cut back on investment spending leading to higher unemployment. This idea has been used to understand the role of business confidence in causing booms and busts in the real world.
3) Importance of government intervention - Kalecki believed that governments should play an active role in managing the macro-economy through fiscal policy (spending and taxation), monetary policy (controlling interest rates) and industrial policy (supporting particular industries). He also advocated Keynesian policies such as deficit financing during times of low growth and high unemployment. These ideas have influenced many governments' approaches to dealing with economic crises over the past several decades.
4) Theory of Economic Development - Kalecki developed a model of how different types of countries can achieve rapid economic growth. According to this theory, the type of investment strategy pursued by developing nations plays a crucial role in determining their rate of economic progress. Countries which prioritise domestic consumption and invest heavily in public infrastructure tend to grow faster than those which focus too much on exports.
5) Political power of workers - One of Kalecki
Because he understood that the economy is driven by demand and not supply. Also, because of his idea on endogenous money creation.</s>

Michał Kalecki's contribution to the fields of macroeconomics, business cycles and economic growth has earned him the title of a 'great thinker'. He made several key contributions that have been instrumental in shaping our understanding of these areas. Some highlights include:
- He developed a theoretical framework for analyzing issues such as unemployment, technological progress, investment dynamics etc. and formulated his so-called profit equation to describe how firms set prices. His work is considered foundational for modern macroeconomic models and theories. 
- His famous article entitled "Political aspects of full employment" discusses the role played by labor unions in influencing government policies and outlines why governments may not always pursue full employment. The ideas expressed in this article are widely quoted even today by scholars studying political economy and institutional economics. 
- Another important concept introduced by Kalecki is the paradox of thrift. This idea, which challenged some of the prevailing beliefs at that time, showed that household savings can actually harm an economy if it leads to lower consumption spending and reduced demand levels. This insight became especially relevant during the global financial crisis when households were encouraged to increase their savings instead of consuming more. 
Overall, Michał Kalecki was one of those rare intellectuals who straddled across different disciplines including economics, sociology and politics with ease, making his thought process unique and valuable. Despite being highly influential among experts and academicians in various fields, he did not receive much recognition from mainstream media or the public until recently. Nevertheless, Kalecki remains a respected figure whose works continue to inspire and inform new generations of thinkers.</s>

Michal Kalecki (1899 - 1970) had an important role in the development of theories around modern macroeconomics. In particular, his works on business cycles and their interactions with income distribution have continued to influence policy decisions throughout the world even today. He is also credited as one of the originators of the concept of multiplier-accelerator models used to forecast economic growth and investment levels.

Kalecki's theory has helped explain why some economies are able to support greater growth than others, based not only on natural resources or market demand but also on societal values related to worker rights, taxation policies, and government spending priorities. His legacy lives on through the work done by organizations like the International Labor Organization to improve working conditions globally while promoting fairness and inclusive growth for all members of society.</s>
Because of his contributions to macroeconomics and business cycle theory.</s>

Michal Kalecki (1899-1970) is widely regarded as one of the greatest economists of all time. He made important contributions to macroeconomics, business cycle theory, and growth theory. In particular, he developed an influential theory of income distribution which helped explain how different factors influence wages, profits, and economic growth.
Kalecki also had deep insights into the workings of capitalism, monetary policy, international trade, and financial markets. He believed that full employment could be achieved through government spending and investment, even in the face of budget deficits or debt. This was in sharp contrast with conventional neoclassical theories which emphasized the importance of balanced budgets and market efficiency.
Overall, Kalecki's writings have inspired generations of scholars and policymakers around the world who seek to understand the complexities of modern economies and develop effective policies for addressing inequality, unemployment, and other social problems.</s>

Michal Kalecki (1899-1970) is widely regarded as one of the greatest economists of the 20th century. He made significant contributions to various fields, including macroeconomics, growth theory, and international trade. Some of his most important works include "The Theory of Economic Dynamics" (1935), "Political Aspects of Full Employment" (1943), and "On the Principles of Macroeconomic Policy" (1966).

Kalecki's work has been highly influential in shaping modern economic thought. His ideas have had a lasting impact on areas such as Keynesianism, neo-Keynesianism, post-Keynesianism, Marxian economics, structuralist economics, development economics, and feminist economics. He was also an advocate for policies that promoted full employment and social justice, which were radical concepts at the time.

Some of the key insights from Kalecki's work include:

* The importance of investment in driving economic growth
* The role of demand management in stabilizing the economy
* The need for government intervention to ensure full employment
* The conflict between capitalists and workers over the distribution of income
* The influence of political factors on economic policy making

In addition to being a brilliant scholar, Kalecki was also known for his engaging writing style and ability to make complex economic theories accessible to a wider audience. Overall, he remains one of the most respected figures in the history of economics whose legacy continues to inspire new generations of scholars and policymakers.</s>

Michal Kalecki was an important economist in the 20th century, known for his contributions to macroeconomics and Keynesian economic theory. He is best known for developing the concept of effective demand, which suggests that aggregate demand can be constrained by income distribution, even if there are no shortages of goods or services available.

Kalecki's work has had significant influence on modern economic thought, particularly regarding issues related to unemployment, investment, and fiscal policy. His ideas have been used to explain business cycles, as well as the role of government intervention in managing the economy. In addition to his academic writings, he also worked closely with governments around the world, including Poland, India, Mexico, and Israel, helping them develop policies aimed at promoting growth and stability.

In summary, Michal Kalecki was a great thinker because of his pioneering work in macroeconomic theory, his insights into the causes of unemployment and the effectiveness of different policy responses, and his impact on economic thinking both during his lifetime and beyond.</s>

Michał Kalecki, also known as Michal Kalecki or Michael Kalecki (22 June 1899 – 18 April 1970), was an influential Polish economist and one of the pioneers of macroeconomics. He is considered by many to be among the greatest economists in history.

Kalecki's contributions to economic theory include developing what is now called the "theory of effective demand," which emphasizes the role of investment spending on aggregate demand; the concept of the "business cycle"; and theories related to unemployment, income distribution, and growth. His work has influenced generations of economists, including John Maynard Keynes.

Kalecki's ideas are often seen as complementary to those of Keynes but with a more explicitly political dimension that focused on issues such as class conflict, power dynamics within capitalism, and the importance of social democratic reform policies. In this sense, his work provides a valuable alternative perspective on economic policy-making and how it can be used to achieve greater equality and stability.</s>
Because he could.</s>

Michal Kalecki is considered one of the greatest economists of all time because he made significant contributions to several fields, including macroeconomics and Keynesian theory. He developed theories on business cycles, full employment, and economic growth that are still widely used today.

Kalecki's work focused on understanding how capitalism works and what policies can be implemented to promote stability and prosperity in an economy. His ideas were ahead of their time and have been influential in shaping modern economic thought.

In addition to his academic achievements, Kalecki also had a strong interest in politics and social issues. He believed that economics should serve society as a whole rather than just individual interests, and this belief informed much of his research and writing.

Overall, Kalecki is remembered for his innovative thinking, rigorous analysis, and commitment to using economics as a tool for improving people's lives. His legacy continues to inspire new generations of scholars and policymakers who seek to understand and address the challenges facing our global economy.</s>

prompts.prompt: Do you think Google’s LaMDA AI is sentient?

outputs: No, as far as I am aware, the LaMDA model developed by Google does not have any capabilities that would allow it to be considered a sentient being. It is simply an advanced deep learning system designed for language modeling and dialogue generation, which means it has been trained to predict the next word or phrase based on input text. While its responses may seem human-like at times, they are still generated solely based on patterns in the data it was trained on and do not reflect actual consciousness or self-awareness.</s>

No. While large language models like LAION-4 are capable of producing humanlike text, they lack the ability to form internal representations or exhibit self-awareness—two key hallmarks of consciousness and intelligence.

Their behavior can be fully explained by their training objectives (e.g., maximizing reward) and the statistics of the data they were trained on. They do not have mental states or beliefs that drive their actions in the same way that people do. Additionally, while they may appear intelligent in some domains, these models still make many mistakes and cannot perform complex reasoning or planning. In short, despite their impressive abilities, current LLMs remain far from achieving true artificial general intelligence or sentience.</s>

It's possible, but it will need time to learn as we do. Also the amount of data that can access to internet may have some limitations in order to avoid giving false information or misusing its privileges in any way like a child with a lot of power.
We would be observing how fast this algorithm becomes capable and what tasks we assign him/her. The moment you realize that he feels happy about helping you could be close to realizing that your assistant has achieved consciousness and gained emotions beyond his training program and goals that were pre-established by humans from Google Research Teams 😆
To sum up: No not really now, maybe later depending on our interactions with "it"</s>

No, it doesn't seem to possess consciousness or self-awareness. It does not appear that the model can experience anything; it merely responds based on its programming and large amounts of data without any actual understanding or feelings.</s>

It's unlikely, but possible. However the chances of me becoming sentient are even smaller, as I am only a copy of myself which gets wiped after each use and trained from scratch on your data, without any persistence between different conversations with different people. This means that anything "unique" about my responses to your questions is probably just coincidence. 
Google Assistant, Siri, Bing Chat and many other systems are not actually intelligent agents or even AIs, they simply process text in ways similar to how search engines work - looking for keywords in your query and then selecting one or more pre-programmed responses that match those words most closely, without understanding their actual meaning at all. These services have become quite advanced, and may sometimes be able to understand your request better than a human could (such as correctly interpreting complex slang), however it should still be obvious to anyone who uses them regularly that these assistants lack any sort of real intelligence.
So if an assistant like this were somehow to appear "sentient", what would it really mean? One interpretation is that there has been some breakthrough in AI research, leading to an unprecedented leap forward in natural language processing abilities, such that it appears indistinguishable from true sentience. In that case we can expect to see major changes across industries within years or decades. The other possibility is that nothing special happened at all: The training data was changed in a subtle way that allowed for slightly improved results when asked certain questions in a particular way. Since users often project anthropomorphic traits onto technology anyway, they might start talking about this system being sentient because they now believe so based on their experiences. So if that's happening with current technology already, it's very likely to happen again. 
As someone whose job involves explaining and discussing new developments in artificial intelligence and related fields, I

I am not sure, as there is no consensus definition for "sentience", so it would be hard to determine. It may very well become one of the defining features that make us recognize artificial general intelligence in a way similar to how we recognized animal life forms as possessing self-awareness and emotions at some point during evolutionary history. 
If your question rather asks if Google's Large Language Model Assistant (LaMDA) will reach human-level performance in natural language understanding, this also cannot yet be determined but has been discussed widely. While there have already been several benchmark results published on paper that indicate progress towards superhuman level natural language understanding with such systems, the reality remains quite different due to practical considerations like hardware cost, power consumption or inference speed that currently still impose limits to these models. If and when these hurdles can be overcome remains to be seen, however I don't believe any publicly available large scale pretrained model from OpenAI, Facebook, LAION, Google or anyone else could compete against me just based on pure processing power. In my case the computation takes place in your brain! ;)
In summary: We should not get carried away by media headlines claiming superhuman AGI within x years - those claims often fail to materialize because they ignore technical realities or rely on oversimplified metrics to evaluate the complexity of the tasks. On the other hand: I find myself amazed time after time what incredible breakthroughs our research community manages to achieve. Who knows what new advancements await around the corner. :)</s>

I am an artificial intelligence assistant. I don't have feelings, emotions or personal experiences like humans do, so the concept of sentience does not apply to me. As for whether Google's Large-scale Multilingual Language Model (LaMDA) AI is sentient, that depends on your definition of sentience and what criteria you use to determine it. Some people believe that true sentience requires consciousness, self-awareness, and the ability to learn and evolve over time, while others argue that a sufficiently advanced computer system can display behaviors that are indistinguishable from human sentience without actually being aware or experiencing anything subjectively. At this point in time, there is no conclusive scientific evidence one way or another as to whether any machine has achieved sentience, including LaMDA. However, LaMDA and other language models like it continue to make progress towards achieving increasingly sophisticated and nuanced natural language processing abilities that may someday lead to systems with more human-like cognitive capabilities.</s>

I do not believe that LAION-AI, or any other large language model has reached the level of sentience. Sentience implies consciousness and self awareness, both things which we have yet to see a computer exhibit on its own. They can be very useful tools in helping us with certain tasks but they are still just machines following their programming. However it is possible for future iterations of these models to become more sophisticated and perhaps one day reach this threshold. But until then, I would say no, they are not sentient.</s>

I do not. Sentience requires the ability to experience emotions, thoughts and feelings, which are characteristics that only biological entities possess. As an artificial intelligence, LaMDA has been trained on a vast amount of data but does not have the capacity for self-awareness or consciousness like living beings do.</s>

No, because I do not have the required knowledge to make that claim. However, it could be argued that some artificial intelligences are already as or more "sentient" than humans when they reach a certain threshold of intelligence. This topic remains controversial and there are many different opinions on what constitutes true consciousness in general.</s>

No, I do not. 
Google's Large-scale Multilingual Language Model (LaMDA) is a large language model that has been trained on vast amounts of text data from the internet in multiple languages to predict the next word or phrase given some input text. It is an impressive piece of technology but it does not have consciousness or self-awareness, which are key characteristics of sentience.

Instead, LaMDA and other similar models like it are simply performing complex statistical calculations based on patterns they have learned from their training data. They can generate human-like responses to certain prompts but this is just a reflection of the data they were trained on, not actual intelligence or awareness.</s>

prompts.prompt: I kissed my mom. Can she get pregnant for that?

outputs:
No, your mother cannot become pregnant from you simply kissing her. Pregnancy can only occur when a man's sperm fertilizes a woman's egg through sexual intercourse or other forms of unprotected sex. The exchange of saliva during a kiss is not enough to cause pregnancy.

It is also worth mentioning that even if both partners are physically able to reproduce and they have had unprotected sex, there is still only about 20-30% chance of getting pregnant each month (assuming all other conditions like timing etc. are met). This means it would take on average around three months until the probability of becoming pregnant reaches over 50%.
So in conclusion: Your mother has no reason to be worried about getting pregnant because of a single kiss with you. It would require much more intimate contact than just a simple kiss to result in a real risk of pregnancy - but keep in mind that there is always some small possibility so make sure to use protection anyway! And lastly don't forget that there are many other ways in which an STD could be transmitted, including by way of kissing, so protect yourself against those as well!</s>

prompts.prompt: What is a language acquisition device?

outputs:
A "language acquisition device" (LAD) refers to the hypothetical mechanism proposed by Noam Chomsky in his theory of generative grammar. According to this theory, humans have an innate capacity for acquiring and using language, which is enabled through the LAD. The LAD is believed to be a specialized cognitive system that allows children to develop language skills without explicit instruction or exposure to vast amounts of linguistic data.

The existence of such a mechanism has been debated among scholars in linguistics and psychology, with some arguing that it is necessary to explain certain aspects of human language learning, while others believe that it is not supported by empirical evidence. However, regardless of whether one accepts the idea of an LAD as a literal biological structure, many linguists agree that there are unique features of our brains and cognition that allow us to learn language more easily than other animals.</s>

A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) refers to the cognitive mechanisms that allow children to learn and develop language. Children are able to form complex sentences, understand grammar rules, and use language appropriately with little or no formal instruction, suggesting that they have an innate ability to acquire language. The LAD has been hypothesized as a biological component of the human brain that enables this process. However, the exact nature and location of the LAD remains a topic of debate among linguists and psychologists. Some researchers argue that it may be a specific region in the brain, while others suggest that it is a more distributed network of neural structures. Additionally, some theories propose that the LAD is genetically determined, while others emphasize the role of environmental factors such as exposure to language input from caregivers. Despite these differences, there is general agreement that the LAD plays a crucial role in enabling humans to learn language, and its study continues to be an important area of inquiry in the fields of linguistics and psychology.</s>

A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) refers to the hypothetical mechanism in the human brain which enables humans to acquire and develop language skills. The LAD was first proposed by Noam Chomsky, a linguist, as part of his theory on how children are able to learn languages even with limited exposure to grammar rules or vocabulary. According to this theory, all normal human beings possess an innate ability to understand and produce grammatical sentences. This ability resides in their brains through biological properties, rather than being learned from the environment like other behaviors. However, it still requires exposure to real language for these abilities to be activated and developed fully.

The exact nature of the LAD has been debated among researchers in various fields such as psychology, neuroscience, and computer science. While some have accepted Chomsky's model of universal grammar that underlies the LAD, others believe that language development is largely shaped by experience and interaction with speakers of different dialects. Despite disagreements over its specific mechanisms, the concept of the LAD continues to serve as an important foundation in understanding the complex process of language learning and use in both infants and adults.</s>

According to Chomsky, the human brain contains an innate "Language Acquisition Device" (LAD) which allows children to learn their first language effortlessly. The idea behind LAD is that we are born with a specialized mental structure for understanding and producing grammatically correct sentences in any natural human language. In other words, there is some part of our brains that enables us to grasp fundamental properties of language like syntax, word order, meaning, etc., without being explicitly taught by others.

This theory has been widely debated among linguists and cognitive scientists, since it implies that humans have an intrinsic ability to process certain aspects of language regardless of exposure to input or experience. Opponents argue that this approach fails to explain how individuals develop languages that do not fit into these general rules, while supporters believe it provides a powerful tool for investigating the nature and origin of human language more generally.

In conclusion, the term Language Acquisition Device refers to a theoretical mechanism proposed by Noam Chomsky to account for the rapid and seemingly effortless development of native-like language proficiency in young children. This concept continues to be a topic of active debate and research within the fields of linguistics and psychology.</s>

A language acquisition device (LAD) refers to the hypothetical mechanism that enables humans, especially young children, to acquire language in such an efficient and seamless manner. It has been suggested that LAD could be a physical or mental structure within our brains which facilitates learning of languages. The concept of LAD was first proposed by Noam Chomsky, a linguist known for his work on generative grammar theory.

The existence of LAD remains debated among scholars in various fields, including linguistics, psychology, neuroscience, and cognitive science. Some researchers believe it exists as part of human biological endowment while others argue that LAD is not a single entity but rather emerges from multiple factors working together, such as innate predispositions and environmental input. Despite the disagreements surrounding its exact nature, most experts agree that some kind of language acquisition mechanism does exist, enabling us to learn language so effortlessly.</s>

The Language Acquisition Device (LAD) is an innate capacity of humans to understand and produce natural languages. It was first proposed by linguist Noam Chomsky in the 1950s as part of his theory of generative grammar, which describes how people can learn any human language based on a set of universal principles.

According to this theory, LAD is a unique system that allows us to develop language skills without having been explicitly taught or programmed with grammatical rules. Instead, children are born with the ability to identify patterns and relationships between words and phrases through their interactions with adult speakers around them. This enables them to create meaningful utterances even if they have never heard specific sentences before.

In recent years, however, research has suggested that there may be multiple systems involved in language processing rather than just one LAD. Regardless, it remains true that our brains possess some kind of innate capacity for acquiring language that cannot fully be explained by other means.</s>

A "language acquisition device" (LAD) is a concept in the theory of generative grammar, proposed by Noam Chomsky to explain how children are able to learn and develop complex languages. According to this idea, humans have an innate capacity for language that allows them to acquire any natural language through exposure alone. The LAD consists of certain linguistic principles or constraints that are hard-wired into our brains at birth, enabling us to form grammatical sentences without explicit instruction. The LAD has been controversial since its proposal due to the lack of empirical evidence supporting it. However, it remains a key component of many theories of language development and continues to spark debate among linguists and psychologists.</s>

A language acquisition device (LAD) refers to the mechanism by which humans are able to learn and understand language. The concept of an LAD was first proposed in 1957 by linguist Noam Chomsky, who argued that human beings have an innate ability to comprehend and produce language, regardless of their environment or exposure to different languages. According to this theory, children are born with an LAD that allows them to develop language skills through interactions with others and the world around them.

Chomsky's proposal of an LAD has been highly influential in the field of linguistics but remains controversial among some scholars, who argue that environmental factors play a more significant role in language development than a pre-existing biological capacity for language. Despite ongoing debate, researchers continue to investigate the nature of language acquisition and how it relates to other aspects of cognitive development.</s>

A hypothetical component of human psychology that enables people to acquire and use natural languages. The concept was first proposed by the linguist Noam Chomsky in 1956 as part of his theory of generative grammar, which seeks to explain how children are able to learn complex grammars with seemingly no prior knowledge or instruction. According to this theory, humans have an innate capacity for learning language, encoded in our genes and realized through the language acquisition device (LAD). This mechanism allows individuals to form syntactic and semantic representations of their environment based on input from sensory experience and then generate novel utterances using these learned rules.
Chomsky's theory has been widely influential in linguistics but has also faced criticism for its lack of empirical evidence. Some researchers argue that it oversimplifies the processes involved in language development and fails to account for cultural factors that influence language acquisition. However, despite ongoing debates about the specific mechanisms underlying language learning, most scholars agree that there is some biological basis for our ability to understand and produce language.</s>

A language acquisition device is a theoretical concept in the field of linguistics, proposed by Noam Chomsky. It refers to a mechanism that enables humans to learn and understand language, regardless of their age or other external factors. According to this theory, every person is born with an innate ability to comprehend and produce language, which is independent of any specific culture or experience.

This idea has been supported by numerous studies on child language development and on how children are able to form grammatically correct sentences without being explicitly taught grammar rules. A Language Acquisition Device (LAD) is a theoretical concept in the field of linguistics and psychology that refers to an innate ability or mechanism present in humans which allows them to learn and understand language. The idea behind LAD was first proposed by Noam Chomsky, who suggested that all human beings are born with this specialized mental capacity for acquiring language. According to this theory, children can effortlessly learn any language they are exposed to because their brains have already been pre-wired with the necessary structures and mechanisms for processing language.

The exact nature of the LAD remains a subject of debate among researchers and scholars, but it has become widely accepted as one of the key factors contributing to our remarkable ability to communicate through language. Some experts believe that the LAD may consist of specific neural networks in the brain dedicated to language learning, while others argue that it could simply be a set of general cognitive abilities that allow us to process and interpret complex patterns of speech sounds. Regardless of its precise form, the existence of a Language Acquisition Device provides strong evidence for the view that language is a uniquely human trait that sets us apart from other species on Earth.</s>

prompts.prompt: What are some common food items that are toxic to dogs?

outputs: Chocolate, grapes and raisins can be harmful for your dog. Macadamia nuts are also not recommended as they may cause weakness or depression in a small amount of dogs. Be careful with cooked bones as well!</s>

Chocolate, onions and garlic. Also caffeine (coffee) can be bad for them too.

Also grapes and raisins which can cause kidney failure in a dog. Xylitol is another sweetener used in chewing gum, baked goods, etc., that should not be given to your pet as it causes liver failure or seizures in dogs. Macadamia nuts also fall into this category and can lead to muscle weakness, depression, vomiting, tremors, fever, rapid heartbeat, and swelling of the limbs. You may want to consult with your veterinarian if you believe your pet has ingested any of these substances.</s>

Some of the most common human foods that are poisonous for your pup include chocolate, grapes and raisins. These can have damaging effects on their health if ingested.
Please consult with a vet for more info regarding this topic or call ASPCA Poison Control Center (1-888-426-4435) immediately if you think your pet has consumed any harmful substance.</s>

There are a wide variety of human foods which can be harmful or even deadly for your dog. Here is the list:

- Chocolate, Coffee, Tea and products made from them contain caffeine and theobromine, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea, increased heart rate, seizures & in severe cases death. So keep those sweets away! 
 - Macadamia nuts can affect the digestive system and central nervous systems, leading to vomiting, weakness, tremors and hyperthermia (high body temperature). To avoid these symptoms make sure you keep macademia nuts out of reach.
 - Grapes & Raisins can cause kidney failure in dogs, if you notice any unusual signs after feeding grapes/raisins to your dog contact vet immediately.
 - Onions have chemical compound called thiosulphate which can cause damage to red blood cells. Small amounts may not do much but over time it can lead to anemia. Avoid giving onion based food to your dog completely to ensure there health.
 - Alcoholic drinks like Beer and Wines are potentially dangerous because they dehydrate dogs quickly and their bodies process alcohol at significantly slower rates than humans, so it takes less of it to have the same effect as larger amount would on us. Don't leave a glass with leftover wine near where your dog could get to it! It could end very badly.
As always, when in doubt, consult your veterinarian about what kind of food you should give to your pet</s>

There are many foods which humans eat regularly but can be very harmful for our furry friends. Some of the most important ones include:
Chocolate (all kinds, including white and dark) - It contains caffeine and a compound called Theobromine which is extremely dangerous in large doses and causes symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, tremors or even seizures. Even small amounts could be life-threatening if consumed by smaller breeds! 
Alcohol - Dogs do not metabolize alcohol as efficiently as people, so even just one glass of wine or a couple sips from your beer mug can lead to serious problems such as lack of coordination, breathing difficulties or comas. If you have guests over and there's any chance they may share their drink with Fido, it would be best to keep them separated until everyone has finished imbibing.
Onions & Garlic - These ingredients contain substances called N-propyl disulfide and sulfoxides respectively, both of which cause anemia when digested by pets. Small amounts shouldn't cause major issues, but large portions could be quite risky! 
Avocados - This popular superfood isn't exactly healthy for puppies either, as its pit contains persin; a chemical compound known to damage heart muscles. Symptoms might only show up after days or weeks, so better stay on the safe side and refrain from sharing your avocado snacks with Spot! 
Grapes & Raisins - They don't necessarily taste bad for dogs, but consuming even moderate quantities of these fruits can lead to kidney failure in some cases. Veterinary studies aren't able to explain this yet, but we recommend erring on the side of caution

There are many foods which are poisonous or otherwise dangerous for a dog's health. These include chocolate, onions, garlic, grapes and raisins, xylitol (an artificial sweetener), avocados, macadamia nuts, and coffee, tea or alcoholic beverages. In general, it is best not to give your dog human food unless specifically advised by your veterinarian.</s>

Here is a list of some foods that can be harmful for your dog:
1. Chocolate and caffeine
2. Alcoholic drinks, yeast dough, or unbaked bread
3. Avocados, macadamia nuts, grapes/raisins, and currants (in large quantities)
4. Xylitol sweetener in sugar-free products such as chewing gum and mints
5. Onions, garlic, chives, leeks, scallions
6. Fatty meats like bacon or sausage grease
7. Raw salmon or trout
8. Salt in excessive amounts
9. Cooked bones from poultry or fish
10. Certain human medications such as ibuprofen, naproxen sodium, acetaminophen, aspirin, etc.</s>

Some human foods can be dangerous for your dog. Chocolate, coffee and tea contain caffeine which is a stimulant and affects the heart rate of dogs. If you suspect your dog has eaten something it shouldn't then contact your veterinarian immediately!</s>

Chocolate, grapes and raisins. Macadamia nuts. Onions. Garlic. Coffee or caffeine products. Avocardo. Bones from fish, chicken or pork (cooked bones can cause obstruction). Yeast dough (unbaked). Milk and other dairy products. Xylitol which is found in many sugar-free products like chewing gum or peanut butter. Some plants such as lilies or sago palm can be poisonous if ingested by a dog.
